How odb Is Coded and Tested
This manual describes how to use odb, a multi-threaded, ODBC-based command-line tool, to perform various operations on a Trafodion database.
, only loading, extracting, and copying data operations are
, meaning that that have been fully tested and are ready to be used in a production environment. Other features are designated as “
,” meaning that they have not been fully tested and are not ready for production use.
This manual is intended for database administrators
who want to run scripts that operate on a Trafodion database
New and Changed Information in This Edition
# this will drop all views in your schema

The Trafodion community encourages your comments concerning this document. We are committed to providing documentation that meets your needs. Send any errors found, suggestions for improvement, or compliments to:
Include the document title, part number, and any comment, error found, or suggestion for improvement you have concerning this document.
odb is available only in a 64
bit version for the Linux platform
linked to the unixODBC driver manager.
able for Linux linked with the unix
Cygwin linked with MS Windows Driver Manager
A general requirement is the ODBC library for the database you want to connect to
In Trafodion Release 1.1, odb is available
This section explains how to install and configure
Grab the source code tarball from
This will install unixODBC under /usr/local and requires root access. If you don’t have root privileges or you want to install unixODBC somewhere else you have to add
to the configure command here above. For example:
Now, in order to configure unixODBC, we have to:
Let’s start with the environment variables (
First you have to set the ODBCHOME variable to the unixODBC installation dir (the one configured via
Then you have to configure the system data sources directory (the one containing odbc.ini and odbcinst.ini). Normally this is the etc/ directory under $ODBCHOME:
Then you have to configure the ODBCINI variable to the full path of the odbc.ini file:
Finally… do not forget to add unixODBC lib directory to your LD_LIBRARY_PATH (Linux) or LIBPATH (IBM AIX) or SHLIB_PATH (HP/UX):
Now we have to configure our data sources in
Trafodion ODBC driver requires an environment variable
ini. This variable must be set to utf16.
If you are using Vertica, t
Vertica ODBC driver requires an additional section named [Driver] in odbc.ini with specific settings for unixODBC (odbcinst library location and UTF level supported by unixODBC).
See the Vertica Programmer’s Guide – Additional ODBC Driver Configuration Settings. See also the following
<< This section is required by Vertica’s ODBC Driver
Another important entry in odbcinst.ini is
. The following comment (extracted from unixODBC sources
If compiled with thread support the DM allows four different
* Level 0 - Only the DM internal structures are protected
* the driver is assumed to take care of it's self
* Level 1 - The driver is protected down to the statement level
* each statement will be protected, and the same for the connect
* level for connect functions, note that descriptors are considered
* equal to statements when it comes to thread protection.
* Level 2 - The driver is protected at the connection level. only
* one thread can be in a particular driver at one time
* Level 3 - The driver is protected at the env level, only one thing
* By default the driver open connections with a lock level of 0,
* drivers should be expecetd to be thread safe now.
* this can be changed by adding the line
* to the driver entry in odbcinst.ini, where N is the locking level
Build: linux, amd64, gcc generic m64, uodbc, mreadline, dynamic gzip, dynamic libhdfs, dynamic libxml2 [Mar 30 2015 00:29:25]
-lsdrv: list available drivers @ Driver Manager level
Connection related options. You can connect using either:
(A)ll object types, (T)table desc, (D)table DDL, (U) table DDL with multipliers
-noschema : do not use schemas: CAT.OBJ instead of CAT.SCH.OBJ
-nocatalog : do not use catalogs: SCH.OBJ instead of CAT.SCH.OBJ
-nocatnull : like -nocatalog but uses NULL instead of empty CAT strings
-ucs2toutf8 : set UCS-2 to UTF-8 conversion in odb
-var var_name var_value: set user defined variables
if script_path_regexp ends with / all files in that dir
if script_path_regexp ends with / all files in that dir
-T max_threads: max number of execution threads
-ldelay #ms: delay (ms) before starting next loop in a thread
-ttime #ms[:ms]: delay (ms) before starting next command in a thread
random delay if a [min:max] range is specified
-b : print start time in the headers when CSV output
-ns nullstring: print nullstring when a field is NULL
-trim: Trim leading/trailing white spaces from txt cols
-drs: describe result set (#cols, data types...) for each Q)
-hint: do not remove C style comments (treat them as hints)
-Z : shuffle the execution table randomizing Qs start order
* loadcmd: default IN. only for Trafodion databases
* loaders: default 2 load threads for each 'extractor'
* direct: only work if target database is Vertica
* loadcmd: default IN. only for Trafodion databases
* loaders: default 1 load threads for each extraction thread
* print: default is Inserted Deleted Changed

You can check commands and SQL scripts with odb using the
(null run) flag. This will just “prepare” (compile) the commands without executing them and fetching the results.
Using Different Data Sources for Different T

Normally all ODBC connections started by odb will use the same Data Source. However, there could be special cases where you want to use different DSN for different threads. In these cases you can use the
ion. This will append to the Data Source name specified via

will use the following (round-robin) DSN/thread association: MYDSN1 for the first thread, MYDSN2 for the second thread and so on. The fifth thread (if any) will use MYDSN1 again. You can use a sequential DSN/thread association by using a ‘+’ sign in front of the
argument. So, for example, if you have 16 threads and
This technique has been used to maximize extraction through
system. Each (local) Data Source was “linked” to a corresponding remote Data Source extracting its own data through its own network interface card.
Normally odb prints query results using a very basic CSV format. Example:
-x "select s_suppkey, s_name, s_phone from tpch.supplier limit 5"
you will get a table format like this:
-x "select s_suppkey, s_name, s_phone from tpch.supplier limit 5" -pad
Sometimes you might want to extract the DDL for multiple objects, In this case you can use % wildcard. For example, the following command will extract the DDL for all tables
odb [2015-04-20 21:33:45]: exiting. Session Elapsed time 2.069 seconds (00:00:02.069)

When porting DDLs from one database to another we should consider possible differences in text column length semantic: certain database use “character oriented” text columns length while other use a “byte oriented” semantic. You can ask odb to multiply text column length when printing DDL using the switch –U[
odb [2015-04-20 21:35:18]: exiting. Session Elapsed time 1.620 seconds (00:00:01.620)
will multiply by 2 the length of “non-wide” text fields and by 4 the length of wide text fields.
You can load a data file using
UPSERT USING LOAD syntax to achieve better throughput as described in

This is a complete list of the data loading operators
The following table describes each data loading operator:
Input file. You can use the following keywords for this field:

This is the field separator. You can define the field separator:
This is the record separator. You can define the record separator the same way as the field separator. Default record separator is ‘\n’ (new line)
Pad character used when loading fixed format files. You can use the same notation as the field separator.
This will use mapfile to map source file to target table columns (see paragraph
This will skip a given number of lines when loading. This can be useful to skip headers in the source file.
This is the max number of records to load. Default is to load all records in the input file
odb will insert NULL when it finds
in the input file. By default the nullstring is the empty string
This is the string qualifier character used to enclose strings. You can define the escape character the same way as the field separator.
This is the character used as escape character. You can define the escape character the same way as the field separator. Default is “\” (back slash).
This defines the size of the I/O buffer for each loading thread. You can define the size of this buffer in two different ways:
- buffer size in kB or MB (for example:
Where to write rejected rows. If you omit this parameter rejected rows will be printed to standard error together with the error returned by the ODBC Driver.
If you add a +sign in front of the file-name, odb will
Will truncate the target table before loading
Will load the target table only if it contains no records
Won’t print the number of records loaded so far during loads
Stop On Error. Will stop as soon as odb will encounter an error
Number of loading threads. odb will use:
- one thread to read from the input file and
error messages per rowset. Normally used with
to limit the number of error messages printed to the standard error
This defines how odb will commit the inserts. You have three choices:
will commit every single insert (see also
load operator). This is the default.
will commit when all rows (assigned to a given thread) have been inserted
This will add /*+ DIRECT */ hint to the insert statement. To be used with Vertica databases in order to store inserted rows “directly” into the ROS (see Vertica’s documentation)
This defines how odb will manage fields longer than the destination target column:
truncate input string, print a warning and
load the truncated field if the
target column is a text field
: like fieldtrunc=0 but no warning message is printed;
: print an error message and does NOT load the row
: like fieldtrunc=0 but tries to load the field even if the target column is NOT a text field
: like fieldtrunc=3 but no warnings are printed.

will be loaded as a valid 2001-10-23 if the target field
This is the character used to embed binary files (see paragraph
). You can define the embed character the same way as the field separator. No default value.
loading the target table. You can, for example, CREATE the target table before loading it.
Target table won’t be loaded if SQL execution fails and Stop On Error is set
immediately after the target table has been loaded. You can, for example, update database stats after loading a table.
is a list of files to be loaded

odb will print what would be loaded in each column but no data is actually loaded. This I useful if you want to see how the input file “fits” into the target tables and is normally used to analyze the first few rows of CSV files (use :max).This option will force:
odb will limit the amount of memory allocated in the ODBC buffers for CHAR/VARCHAR fields to #bytes
odb will print a “timeline” (milliseconds from start) for each insert
Bytes allocated in the ODBC buffer for each (non wide) CHAR/VARCHAR column length unit (default 1)
Bytes allocated in the ODBC buffer for each (wide) CHAR/VARCHAR column length unit (default 4)
Input file is XML. Load all
under the one specified with this option. If a plus sign is specified, odb will load node attributes values.

target table columns with XML node or attributes using their names. If this option is specified odb will load the first node/attribute to the first column, the second node/attribute to the second column and so on without checking node/attribute names
Using this option odb won’t load the XML file content. XML attribute/tage names are printed to standard output so you can check what is going to be loaded.
SQL operation to be used for load,
default is INSERT. UPSERT and UPSERT USING LOAD are also available for Trafodion
You can load multiple files using different
options. By default odb will create as many threads (and ODBC connections) as the sum of parallel load threads. You can limit this number using
Will truncate and load (CUSTOMER, ORDERS and LINEITEM) tables. Input files have the same name as the target tables – in lower cases). Loads will be distributed among available threads this way:
If you want to load more than one table in parallel you should use a number of threads defined as:
ou can load gzipped files without any special option. odb will automatically check input files and decompress them on the fly when needed
Also note that, even using one single loading thread (
), odb is faster than without parallel. This because if we do not specify parallel, odb will use one thread to both read from file and write into the target table:
Read buffer #1 > Write Buffer #1 > Read Buffer #2 > Write Buffer #2 > Read Buffer #3 > Write Buffer #3 ..
we have one thread to read from file and one to write:

Now reading from file is – normally – much faster than writing via ODBC so a single “reading thread” can serve different “loading threads”. One could ask: what the “right” number of loading threads is?

In order to define the right number of loading threads you should run a few test and monitor the “Wait Cycles” reported by odb. Wait Cycles represent the number of times the “reading thread” had to wait for one “loading thread” to become available. When you have high “Wait Cycles/Total Cycles” ratio... it’s better to increase the number of writers. When the “Wait Cycles/Total Cycles” is less than 5%, adding more loading threads is useless or counterproductive.

, assumes that input files contain as many fields as the target table columns. Also: file fields and target table columns are in the same order. This means that the first field in the input file will be loaded in the first table column, second input field will go to the second column and so on.
If this basic assumption is not true and you need more flexibility to “link” input fields to target table columns, odb provides mapping/transformation capabilities though “mapfiles”. By specifying
Associate any input file field to any table column
Replace input file strings. For example: insert ‘Maurizio Felici’ when you read ‘MF’
to link input file fields to the corresponding target table columns. Mappings use the following syntax:
is the target table column name
) of the input file field. So: first input field is ‘0’ (zero), second input field is ‘1’ and so on
to generate/load a sequence starting from
to generate/load a random integer between
to generate/load a random date (YYYY-MM-DD) between
: to generate/load a random time (hh:mm:ss) between 00:00:00 and 23:59:59
: to generate/load a random timestamp (YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss) between midnight UTC – 01 Jan 1970 and the current timestamp
will generate/load a string of <LENGTH> characters randomly selected in the following ranges: a-z, A-Z, 0-9
will generate/load a random NUMERIC field with precision
will select and load a random line from
: will select and load a random portion of test from
will select and load a random value from
will generate and load a string made of
is a string of random characters (a-z, A-Z, 0-9) with length between
is a string of random characters (a-z, A-Z, 0-9) with length between
is a randomly selected suffix from
to load the current timestamp (YYYY-MM-SS hh:mm:ss)
to load fixed format fields made of
: will load empty strings in the input file as NULLs (default is to load empty string as… empty strings)
will load empty fields in the input file as
. For example if you have an input field containing “__Tib:student” a transformation rule like SUBSTR:3:6 will load “Tib” in the database.

. This operator convert timestamps from the input file format defined through <FORMAT> to YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS before loading. The input format is defined through any combination of the following characters:
ignore up to the next digit
. This operator convert dates from the input file format defined through <FORMAT> to YYYY-MM-DD (see TSCONV operator).
. This operator convert times from the input file format defined through <FORMAT> to HH:MM:SS (see TSCONV operator).
. This operator will load the string <WRITTEN> when the input file fields contains <READ>. If the input file string doesn’t match <READ> it will be loaded as is (see paragraph
. This operator converts the string read from the input file to uppercase before loading.
. This operator converts the string read from the input file to lowercase before loading.
. This operator converts the first character of the string read from the input file to uppercase and the remaining characters to lowercase before loading. Example: proGRAmMEr
This opertator let you to delete or change any character with another. Examples:
WORK:7:translit:Gp:HP will load the seventh input field into the target column named WORK and will replace all “G” with “H” and all “p” with “P”
WORK:7:translit:Gp\r:HP\d behaves like the previous example but will also delete all “carriage returns” (\r)

. This operator is somehow similar to SUBSTR but instead of using fixed position to extract substrings will use delimiting characters. For example, suppose your input fields (comma is the field separator) are:

The simpler way to load database generated defaults is to ignore the associated columns in the map file. For example, suppose you have a table like th
id largeint generated by default as identity not null,
If you have an input file containing:
First column (ID) will be loaded with its default value (not in the map file)
Second column (FNAME) will be loaded with the second input field from file (FNAME:1)
Third column (LNAME) will be loaded with its default value (not in the map file)
Fourth column (BDATE) will be loaded with the Current Data generated by odb (BDATE:CDATE)
And the Fifth column (COMMENT) will be loaded with the fifth column in the input file (COMMENT:4)
Assuming your backend database (and your ODBC Driver) supports BLOB data types, or equivalent, you can use odb to directly load binary (or any other) files into a database column using the [
] symbol to identify the file to be loaded into that specific database field.

odb will consider the string following the “em” character as the path of the file to be loaded in that specific field.
load rows where the size of the input file is greater than the target database column

odb will allocate memory for the ODBC buffers during load/extract operations based on the max possible length of the source/target columns. So, if you have a column defined as VARCHAR(2000), odb will allocate enough space for 2,000 characters in the ODBC buffer.

Now, if you know in advance that you will never load/extract 2,000 characters you can limit the amount of space allocated by odb. This will reduce memory usage and increase performances because of the reduced network traffic.
Suppose we have a table like this:
The max length of the second field in this file is:
In this case you can use
to limit the amount of the ODBC buffer:
odb [2015-04-20 21:46:12]: exiting. Session Elapsed time 1.294 seconds (00:00:01.294)
If you do not specify this parameter odb will allocate the buffer for the max possible length of each field:
odb [2015-04-20 21:47:14]: exiting. Session Elapsed time 1.373 seconds (00:00:01.373)

the extraction process will use three threads (ODBC connection)

If the values are not equally distributed data extraction will be deskewed.

Stop On Error. Will stop as soon as odb will encounter an error
odb will use as many threads as the parallel argument to extract data from partitioned source tables
an equivalent number of threads to write to the target table. For example if you specify
and the source table is made of 32 partitions, odb will start
threads (four ODBC connections) to read from the source table
four threads (four ODBC connections) to write to the target table:
- thread 0 will extract partitions 0-7 from source
- thread 1 will write data extracted from thread 0 to target
- thread 2 will extract partitions 8-15 from source
- thread 3 will write data extracted from thread 2 to target
- thread 4 will extract partitions 16-23 from source
- thread 5 will write data extracted from thread 4 to target
- thread 6 will extract partitions 24-31 from source
- thread 7 will write data extracted from thread 6 to target
This option is used in conjunction with parallel to copy only records satisfyi
he where condition is limited to columns in the source table.
For example: you want to copy records with TRANS_TS > 1999-12-12 09:00:00 from the source table
.MAURO.MFORDERS using 8 parallel streams to a target table having the same name as the source table:

Using Case-Sensitive Table and Column N
The possibility to use case sensitive table/column names depends on your database configuration. odb will maintain table/column case sensitiveness when they are enclosed in double quotes.
.MAURIZIO.Names table made of three columns: “name”, “NAME” and “Name”
Double quotes have to be escaped under *nix. A few examples:
You can omit double quotes around column names
Determining the Appropriate Number of Threads for Load/Extract/Copy/Di

If you have to load/extract or copy multiple tables in parallel the best option is to use the options :tpar=number and :parallel=number. The first option (:tpar) defines how many tables have to be copied/extracted in parallel; the second option defines how many “data streams” to use for each table. This way odb will automatically allocate and start the “right” number of threads.
when copying/loading or extracting tables is to use as many “data streams” as:
min(number of middletier CPUs, number of source CPUs, number of target CPUs)
The number of threads started for each “data stream” depend on the operation type:
One thread to read from file + one thread per parallel to load
One thread per parallel to extract
Two threads per parallel: read from source and write to target
Three threads per parallel: read from source, read from target, compare
There are basically two ways to integrate a generic database with Hadoop using odb:

First Option is to use HIVE (Hadoop DWH) and its ODBC Driver. In this case odb can access HIVE like any other “normal” relational database. So – for example – you can copy to from HIVE and other databases using odb’s copy option
Second option if to add the
prefix to the input or output file during loads/extracts. In this case the file will be read/written from/to Hadoop. odb interacts directly with the HDFS file system using
. This option is currently available only under Linux.
You can use odb to compare two tables
on different databases. In order to compare the two tables odb will:
extract source/target tables ordered by Primary Key or any other set of columns (see key option here below)
compare source/target ODBC buffers without “unpacking” them into columns/rows.
Each “comparison stream” is made of three threads:
One reading from the source table
One reading from the target table
These three threads work in parallel: the “compare” thread will check buffer N
the other two threads extract the net block of data from the source/target database in parallel.
You can have multiple “triplets” working in parallel on different section of the table using the
operator. For example the following command:
The comparison threads use double buffering and advanced memory comparison techniques.
can provide the following information in output as a CSV file:

New rows on target (‘I’ – inserted – rows) based on the
columns but with different values in other fields). For these rows odb can print the original source version (‘C’ rows) and/or the modified target version (‘U’ rows).

Check the rest on your o
All the following are case insensitive:
c | connect { no | [user[/pswd][;opts;...] (re/dis)connect using previous or new user
odb odb_command : will run an odb instance using the same DSN/credentials
@file [&0]... [&9] : execute the sql script in file
set chsch [cmd] : show/set change schema command
set cols [#cols] : show/set ls number of columns
set cwd [<directory>] : show/set current working directory
set fs [<char>] : show/set file field separator
set hist [#lines] : show/set lines saved in the history file
set maxfetch [#rows] : show/set max lines to be fetched (-1 = unlimited)
set nocatalog [on|off] : show/enable/disable "no catalog" database mode)
set nocatnull [on|off] : show/enable/disable "no catalog as null" database mode)
set noschema [on|off] : show/enable/disable "no schema" database mode)
set nullstr [<string>] : show/set string used to display NULLs (* to make it Null)
set param name [value|-]: show/set/change/delete a parameter
set pcn [on|off] : show/enable/disable printing column names
set plm [on|off] : show/enable/disable print list mode (one col/row)
set query_timeout [s] : show/set query timeout in seconds (def = 0 no timeout)
set rowset [#] : show/set rowset used to fetch rows
set soe [on|off] : show/enable/disable Stop On Error mode
set spool [<file>|off] : show/enable/disable spooling output on <file>
<SQL statement>; : everything ending with ';' is sent to the database
Control-A : move to beginning of line Control-P : history Previous
Control-E : move to end of line Up Arrow : history Previous
Control-B : move cursor Back Control-N : history Next
Left Arrow : move cursor Back Down Arrow : history Next
Control-F : move cursor Forward Control-W ; history List
Right Arrow: move cursor Forward Control-R : Redraw
Control-D : input end (exit) - DEL right Control-V : Edit current line
Control-L : Lowercase Line Control-X : Kill line
Control-U : Uppercase Line #Control-G : load history entry #
When the odb SQL Interpreter starts it looks for the
. This Initialization File is made of
containing the commands to be executed. To find the Initialization File, odb will:
If this variable is not set, odb will
look for a file named “.odbrc” (*nix) or “_odbrc”
identified by names between square brackets. For example, the following
set alias count "select row count from &1;"
set alias size "select sum(current_eof) from table (disk label statistics (&1) );

set alias ll "select left(object_name, 40) as object_name, sum(row_count) as nrows, count(partition_num) as Nparts, sum(current_eof) as eof from table(disk label statistics( using (select * from (get tables in schema &catalog.&schema, no header, return full names) s(b) ))) group by object_name order by object_name;"
odb SQL Interpreter will automatically run all commands in the
). A section named DEFAULT will be executed when -I has no arguments.
You can define your prompt through the
command when running the SQL Interpreter.

set prompt "Prompt for %U connected via %D to %S in %M mode > "

Under Cygwin, Unix and Linux (and probably under Windows too using ANSI.SYS driver
not tested) you can use standard ANSI escape color codes
(ASCII 001 and 002) before and after each color code sequence;
is a "real" Escape Character and the meaning of the ANSI color codes are:
uses Condition Variables to synchronize threads during copy and parallel load operations.

Most of the memory allocation operations are dynamic. So, for example, you can execute an SQL command as long as you want (in previous version of odb maximum SQL command length was 8192 bytes). However, I found it convenient to "hard code" the following limits
systems (notably the Linux Loader) have huge default stack size. Due to this insane value
you can have errors like this when starting tens/hundreds of threads:
Error starting cmd thread #: cannot allocate memory
If you get this error check your default stack
stack size (kbytes, -s) 204800 << this is the problem
and reset it to sane values (value will be reset to the initial value when you start a new session). For example:
If you get errors like this:
[0] odb(5020) - [Oracle][ODBC]Optional feature not implemented. (State: HYC00 Native Err: 0)
to your command line. When the backend database doesn’t use catalogs you should use an
as catalog name. Some buggy ODBC Drivers unfortunately want NULL here – instead of
You can have errors loading TIME(N) fields with N>0 under

www.splint.org) to statically check the source code
You can update missing statistics with a single line command like this:

./odb64luo -u xyx -p yyy -d zzz -N -S test/queries/Q*.sql 2>&1 | sed -n 's/^.*WARNING\[600[7-8]\].*column\? \(.*\) from table \(.*\) were.*$/UPDATE STATISTICS FOR TABLE \2 ON \1;/p' | ./odb64luo -u xyz -p xyz -d mft -f –
option will prevent their real execution) and write warnings/errors on the standard output.
sed -n 's/^.*WARNING\[600[7-8]\].*column\? \(.*\) from table \(.*\) were.*$/UPDATE STATISTICS FOR TABLE \2 ON \1;/p'
will transform the warnings into real UPDATE STATISTICS statements.
will run the UPDATE STATISTICS statements built with the previous sed (
means that commands are provided via standard input).
Getting All DDL Statements in a Given Schema
You can copy and paste these aliases in your $ODB_INI file:
# Fully Qualified Host Name or IP
Be aware: this is case sensitive.
spaces”: blank, tab, new line, carriage return, form feed, vertical tab

When the source table column is defined as NOT NULL and the specific field contains only blanks, odb will leave in the output file one single blank. This will help to distinguish between NULL fields (
) and NOT NULL fields containing all blanks (
